awake.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: She was still only half awake when I brought her a cup of coffee.
How do you stay awake during boring lectures?
Emma lay awake half the night, worrying.
The noise brought him wide awake  (=completely awake).
To keep themselves awake  (=stop themselves from going to sleep) they sat on the floor and told each other stories.
awake.translation[0].note_box[0].section: I was tired and it was hard to stay awake.
Kate lay awake thinking about what had happened.
The noise of the airplanes kept me awake.
Ben shook me awake and told me the news.
I'm never wide awake until I've had a cup of coffee.
Most of the people on the train were only half awake.
George, barely awake, came stumbling down the stairs.
awake.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to wake up, or to make someone wake up
awake.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: It was midday when she awoke.
We awoke to a day of brilliant sunshine.
awake.translation[1].definitions[0].note: In everyday English, people usually use wake up rather than awake:
I woke up at 4 o'clock this morning.
awake.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: if something awakes an emotion, or if an emotion awakes, you suddenly begin to feel that emotion
awake.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: The gesture awoke an unexpected flood of tenderness towards her.
